title.narrative: OUTPUT 1.4 NUTRITION

description.narrative: Output 1.4 By 2025, the Government and stakeholders at national and subnational level will have increased capacity to expand and sustainably provide a package of high impact nutrition interventions for infants, children, adolescents and women of reproductive age in development and humanitarian situations, and urban settings, which contributes to Early Detection And Treatment Of Malnutrition, Early Detection And Treatment Of Malnutrition (Covid), Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence, Nutrition In Early Childhood, Nutrition Of Adolescents And Women. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Community Engagement, Social And Behaviour Change, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: 1.By 2025, new-borns, children and adolescent boys and girls, especially the most disadvantaged and those living in humanitarian situations, have increased access to and use of quality integrated health, nutrition, HIV and early stimulation services and benefit from a more nurturing, protective and clean environment

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Output 1.4 By 2025, the Government and stakeholders at national and subnational level will have increased capacity to expand andsustainably provide a package of high impact nutrition interventions for infants, children, adolescents and women of reproductiveage in development and humanitarian situations, and urban settings

description.narrative: UNICEF support to the development of a Nutrition Investment case for Uganda, validation of the Regulatory Impact Assessment for the draft National Nutrition Policy and the development of the national nutrition repository and dashboard contributed to further strengthening the enabling environment for nutrition. At service delivery level, 2,185,519 children aged 6–59 months received Vitamin A supplementation and 37,950 were treated for severe acute malnutrition with UNICEF support. COVID-19 accentuated the underlying and immediate causes of child undernutrition, including inadequate diets, sub-optimal health services, poor childcare practices, and food insecurity. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:09/01/2022
